questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with complaints of pain in his calves during and after physical activity. Upon further evaluation, including a detailed examination and muscle biopsy, it was noted that there was an increased glycogen accumulation in the muscle tissues. Based on these findings, which of the following enzymes is most likely deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Muscle phosphorylase

 

Option A:

 

The given clinical case scenario is a Glycogen storage disorder, Type V – McArdle’s syndrome caused by defective muscle Glycogen Phosphorylase

 

Explanation:

 

Option B.  Liver phosphorylase kinase: Is a type VIII disorder with hepatomegaly, accumulation of glycogen in liver and mild hypoglycaemia.

 

Option C. Glucose 6 phosphatase: Is deficient in Von Gierke disease (Ia), C/F includes glycogen accumulation in liver and renal tubule cells, hypoglycaemia, lactic academia, ketosis and hyperlipemia.(No muscle weakness).

 

Option D.  Branching enzyme: Is defective in Andersen disease with Hepatosplenomegaly; accumulation of polysaccharide with few branch points; death from heart or liver failure before age 5.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: P 179.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male with a history of short stature presents to the clinic with recurrent episodes of hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, and bleeding tendencies. On examination, the patient also has notable hepatomegaly and enlarged kidneys. Laboratory findings include elevated levels of lactate, cholesterol, triglycerides, and uric acid. Considering the constellation of symptoms and lab findings, which enzyme deficiency is most likely responsible for this patient's clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Glucose-6-phosphatase   

 

Option D:

                                         

  • The patient is having classic signs and symptoms of Von Gierke disease. It is due to deficiency of the enzyme glucose-6-phosphatase. This disease usually manifests in the first 12 months of life. 
  • Lab results reveal increased lactate, cholesterol, triglyceride and uric acid levels.  This condition is caused by a basic enzyme.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A.  Branching enzyme: deficiency results in Anderson disease. C/F: failure to thrive, liver failure, and hypotonia.

 

Option B.  Debranching enzyme: deficiency results in Cori disease. C/F: hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, short-stature, and myopathy. 

 

Option C. Muscle phosphorylase: deficiency results in McArdle disease. C/F: pain, cramps and myoglobinuria on strenuous exercise.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Von Gierke's disease (Type I glycogen storage disease), characterized by a deficiency in glucose-6-phosphatase. This enzyme is crucial for the final steps of gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis, converting glucose-6-phosphate into free glucose. Its deficiency leads to impaired glucose production, resulting in hypoglycemia, and the accumulation of glycogen and fat in the liver and kidneys, causing hepatomegaly and renal enlargement. The increased levels of lactate, cholesterol, triglycerides, and uric acid are also consistent with the metabolic disturbances seen in von Gierke's disease.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:  p 179,355

questions.text: In a pediatric grand rounds presentation, a challenging case involving a 6-month-old infant with recurrent episodes of early morning hypoglycemia is discussed. The attending physician explains that administering glucagon raised the infant's blood glucose levels when fed but was ineffective during fasting periods. A liver biopsy revealed abnormal glycogen accumulation. The audience, consisting of pediatricians JRs, is then asked to determine the enzyme deficiency responsible for the infant's condition based on the clinical findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. A)  Debranching enzyme

 

Option A:       

                                           

  • The most probable diagnosis is Glycogen storage diseases: Cori’s / Limit dextrinosis, Forbes disease (Type IIIa) - deficient liver and muscle debranching enzyme.
  • Clinical presentation includes fasting hypoglycaemia, hepatomegaly, accumulation of branched polysaccharide (limit dextrin) & muscle weakness.
  • In fed state, glycogen is present. So, glucagon stimulates enzyme phosphorylase to cleave glycogen there by releasing glucose to circulation. In fasting state, there is only limit dextrin and no effect of glucagon on debranching enzyme. Hence, the glucagon will not raise the blood glucose levels.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Muscle phosphorylase: Type V – McArdle’s syndrome; Poor exercise tolerance with high muscle glycogen and low blood lactate after exercise.

 

Option C. Glucose-6-phosphatase: Is deficient in Von Gierke disease (Ia),C/F includes glycogen accumulation in liver and renal tubule cells, hypoglycaemia, lactic academia, ketosis and hyperlipidemia.

 

Option D. Branching enzyme: Is defective in Anderson disease with Hepatosplenomegaly; accumulation of polysaccharide with few branch points; death from heart or liver failure before age 5.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The clinical features of Type III Glycogen Storage Disease (Cori's or Forbes' Disease) caused by a deficiency in the debranching enzyme, leading to impaired glycogenolysis, glycogen accumulation in the liver, and fasting hypoglycemia.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 179.

choices.text: Muscle debranching enzyme

questions.text: A 25-year-old male visits his primary care physician complaining of recurrent episodes of pain in his calves triggered by physical activity. He reports no other symptoms or significant medical history. Given the concern for a metabolic muscle disorder, a muscle biopsy is performed, revealing an accumulation of glycogen within the muscle cells. Based on the patient's symptoms and biopsy findings, which enzyme deficiency is most likely responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Muscle Phosphorylase

 

Option B:

 

The patient's presentation is indicative of McArdle's disease (Type V glycogen storage disease), characterized by a deficiency in muscle phosphorylase. This enzyme is crucial for glycogenolysis in muscle tissue, and its deficiency leads to an inability to break down glycogen into glucose during exercise, resulting in muscle pain and cramping. The accumulation of glycogen in muscle biopsy further supports this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Muscle debranching enzyme: Deficiency in the muscle debranching enzyme leads to Cori's disease (Type III glycogen storage disease), which typically presents with more systemic symptoms, including hepatomegaly, in addition to muscle weakness.

 

Option C. Glucose 6 phosphatase: Deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase characterizes von Gierke's disease (Type I glycogen storage disease), primarily affecting liver function and leading to hypoglycemia, not isolated muscle symptoms.

 

Option D. Branching enzyme: A deficiency in the branching enzyme results in Andersen's disease (Type IV glycogen storage disease), which is associated with liver dysfunction and progressive cirrhosis, rather than isolated muscle symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 179.

choices.text: Decreased availability of glucose to tissues

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents to the pediatric clinic with recurrent episodes of hypoglycemia, especially noted during fasting periods. The child's growth parameters are below the normal percentile for age. Laboratory investigations reveal lactic acidosis and hyperuricemia. After further evaluation, the child is diagnosed with Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency. The attending physician explains to the parents the association between the child's condition and the development of hyperuricemia and gout. Which of the following is the most likely cause of hyperuricemia and gout in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) More formation of pentoses

 

Option B:

 

Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency, also known as Glycogen Storage Disease Type I (GSD I), leads to an inability to convert glucose-6-phosphate into glucose, resulting in the trapping of glucose within cells and subsequent hypoglycemia. To compensate for the lack of available glucose, the body increases the breakdown of nucleic acids to produce more glucose through gluconeogenesis, leading to an excess production of purine bases. The increased turnover of these purine bases ultimately results in the overproduction of uric acid, a precursor to gout. This pathway also leads to an increased formation of pentoses, which are involved in the synthesis of nucleic acids, thus contributing to the cycle of purine breakdown and uric acid production.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Decreased availability of glucose to tissues: This is a direct consequence of Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency leading to hypoglycemia but does not directly cause hyperuricemia and gout. The lack of glucose exacerbates the metabolic imbalance but isn't the primary cause of increased uric acid levels.

 

Option C. Increased accumulation of sorbitol: Sorbitol accumulation is associated with conditions like diabetes mellitus due to increased activity of the polyol pathway when glucose levels are high. It is not directly related to Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency or hyperuricemia and gout in this context.

 

Option D. Impaired degradation of free radicals: While oxidative stress and impaired degradation of free radicals can contribute to cellular damage and various metabolic disturbances, they are not directly involved in the mechanism leading to hyperuricemia and gout in patients with Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Biochemical defect in von Gierke’s disease:

 

Deficiency of Glucose 6 Phosphatase  → accumulation of Glucose 6 Phosphate → it is  channelled to Pentose Phosphate pathway → more Pentoses are formed → enters Purine Synthesis → Uric acid accumulates (degradation product of Purine)

 

Ref: Nelson 20/e: Defects in the metabolism of Carbohydrates

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant is presented to the pediatric outpatient department by the mother, reporting symptoms of rapid heart rate, restlessness, muscle hypotonia, and abdominal distention. The infant has been diagnosed with cardiac failure and is currently being treated with diuretics and an ACE inhibitor. Radiographic evidence indicates left ventricular hypertrophy, and physical examination reveals hepatosplenomegaly. An assay performed on a dried blood spot indicates reduced activity of a specific enzyme, leading to a diagnosis of Pompe disease. Which enzyme deficiency is associated with Pompe disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acid maltase 

 

Option B:

 

Pompe disease, also known as Glycogen Storage Disease Type II, is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme acid alpha-glucosidase, also known as acid maltase. This lysosomal enzyme is responsible for breaking down glycogen into glucose within lysosomes. Its deficiency leads to the accumulation of lysosomal glycogen, particularly affecting cardiac and skeletal muscles, as well as the liver. The hallmark features of Pompe disease include cardiomyopathy (often presenting as cardiac failure in infants), muscle weakness (hypotonia), and hepatomegaly. The diagnosis is supported by enzyme assays showing reduced acid maltase activity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Branching enzyme: deficiency results in Anderson disease. C/F: failure to thrive, liver failure, and hypotonia.

 

Option C. Muscle phosphorylase: deficiency results in McArdle disease. C/F: pain, cramps and myoglobinuria on strenuous exercise.

 

Option D. Glucose-6-phosphatase: Deficiency results in Von Gierke disease. C/F: Hypoglycaemia; hyperketonaemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 179.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old girl child is admitted with progressive abdominal distension for the past 6 months. Mother reported that the baby has difficulty in walking, gets easily tired while playing and restless and sweat in early morning hours. After giving juice or milk, she feels comfortable. On examination, child was found to have motor retardation and was small for age. Liver was found to be enlarged with firm consistency.

 

Laboratory investigations:

 

FBS: 60 mg/dl (normal = 80-110 mg/dl)

AST: 355 IU/L (normal = 15-45 IU/L)

ALT: 244 IU/L (normal = 15-45 IU/L)

ALP: 231 IU/L (normal =98-279 IU/L)

Total bilirubin: 2.0 mg/dl (normal = 0-1.0 mg/dl)

Liver histology: Glycogen laden vacuoles with no fibrosis or inflammatory cell infiltration.

 

 

Baby was diagnosed with GSD type III based on the results.  What is the causative enzyme deficiency in this disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Debranching enzyme  

 

Option B:

 

Glycogen Storage Disease (GSD) Type III, also known as Cori disease or Forbes disease, is caused by a deficiency in the debranching enzyme (amylo-1,6-glucosidase, 4-alpha-glucanotransferase). This enzyme is crucial for the breakdown of glycogen, specifically in removing branch points in glycogen. A deficiency in this enzyme leads to the accumulation of abnormal glycogen with short outer branches, which is evident in the liver histology of the patient as glycogen-laden vacuoles. This accumulation disrupts normal glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis, leading to symptoms such as hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, and growth retardation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Branching enzyme: deficiency results in Anderson disease. C/F: failure to thrive, liver failure, and hypotonia.

 

Option C.  Muscle phosphorylase: deficiency results in McArdle disease. C/F: pain, cramps and myoglobinuria on strenuous exercise.

 

Option D. Glucose-6-phosphatase: Deficiency results in Von Gierke disease. C/F: Hypoglycemia; hyperketonaemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 179.

choices.text: If the fasting plasma sugar is more than 126 mg /dl, on more than one occasion
If 2-hr post-glucose load value of GTT is more than 200 mg /dl (even at one occasion).
If the random plasma sugar level is more than 200 mg/dl, on more than one occasion.

questions.text: Which of the following options correctly represents the diagnostic criteria for Diabetes Mellitus?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All the above

 

Option D:

 

The diagnostic criteria for Diabetes Mellitus include several key measurements, each of which can independently confirm the diagnosis:

 

Fasting Plasma Glucose (FPG): A value of 126 mg/dl (7.0 mmol/l) or higher, confirmed on more than one occasion, indicates diabetes. Fasting is defined as no caloric intake for at least 8 hours.

 

2-hour Plasma Glucose During an Oral Glucose Tolerance Test (OGTT): A value of 200 mg/dl (11.1 mmol/l) or higher at the 2-hour mark during an OGTT, using a glucose load of 75 grams, confirms the diagnosis. This criterion does not necessarily require confirmation on a second occasion if the patient presents with classic symptoms of hyperglycemia.

 

Random Plasma Glucose: A value of 200 mg/dl (11.1 mmol/l) or higher, in a patient with classic symptoms of hyperglycemia (e.g., polyuria, polydipsia, unexplained weight loss), can confirm the diagnosis of diabetes without the need for fasting or an OGTT.

 

Given that each of these criteria can independently diagnose Diabetes Mellitus, option D) All the above is correct.

 

 Explanation:

 

Option A. Fasting plasma sugar more than 126 mg/dl, on more than one occasion: This is one of the criteria for diagnosing diabetes but not the only one.

 

Option B.  2-hour post-glucose load value of GTT more than 200 mg/dl: This too is a valid criterion for diagnosing diabetes, even if observed on just one occasion, provided there are classic symptoms of hyperglycemia.

 

Option C. Random plasma sugar level more than 200 mg/dl, on more than one occasion: While a single measurement with classic symptoms can be sufficient, additional confirmation enhances the diagnostic certainty, especially in asymptomatic individuals.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • If the fasting plasma sugar is more than 126 mg /dl, on more than one occasion
  • If 2-hr post-glucose load value of GTT is more than 200 mg /dl (even at one occasion).
  • If the random plasma sugar level is more than 200 mg/dl, on more than one occasion.
  • Glycated haemoglobin (Glyco -Hb) or HbA1c level more than 6.5% at any occasion

 

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/e: 314.

choices.text: They are often associated with deficient enzyme activity.
Both alleles contain the same mutation.
They are more variable than autosomal dominant conditions.
Most persons do not carry any abnormal recessive genes.

questions.text: In the context of type IV glycogen storage disease (GSD IV), an autosomal recessive condition characterized by progressive liver damage, hypoglycemia, hyperlipidemia, and hyperuricemia due to deficient glycogenolysis, which of the following statements accurately describes autosomal recessive conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. They are often associated with deficient enzyme activity.

 

Option A:

 

  • Autosomal and X-linked recessive inheritance is seen in almost all metabolic diseases as seen in type IV glycogen storage disease.
  • Traits such as deafness can follow any of the three major mendelian inheritance mechanisms (genetic heterogeneity) tend to be more severe in recessive rather than dominant forms, and recessive conditions are less variable than dominant phenotypes.
  • Most mattings involve persons who have mutations at different loci, hence related persons are more likely to inherit the same mutant gene, consanguinity increases the possibility of homozygous affected offspring.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Both alleles are defective but do not contain the exact same mutation.

 

Option C: They have a horizontal pattern of affected persons in the pedigree. Males and females are affected with equal frequency and severity.

 

Option D: All individuals carry 6 to 12 mutant recessive alleles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Autosomal recessive conditions, such as type IV glycogen storage disease, are frequently characterized by a deficiency in enzyme activity. This is because both copies of the gene in question (one from each parent) must be affected for the disorder to manifest, typically resulting in the absence or malfunctioning of an enzyme or protein.

 

Ref: Harper 31/e, p 820-821

questions.text: Which of the following glycogen storage diseases typically spares the muscles from involvement?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Type I

 

Option A:

 

Glycogen Storage Disease Type I, also known as Von Gierke disease, primarily affects the liver and kidneys and is characterized by the deficiency of the enzyme glucose-6-phosphatase. This enzyme is crucial for the final steps of gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis, allowing glucose to be released into the bloodstream. Due to the enzyme's absence in muscle tissue, GSD Type I does not directly involve muscle pathology.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Type II: Type II, or Pompe disease, involves lysosomal alpha-1,4-glucosidase deficiency and affects cardiac and skeletal muscles, leading to progressive muscle weakness.

 

Option C. Type V: Type V, known as McArdle disease, specifically affects muscle phosphorylase and is characterized by muscle cramps and exercise intolerance, indicating direct muscle involvement.

 

Option D. Type VII: Type VII, or Tarui disease, involves phosphofructokinase deficiency in muscle cells, leading to exercise intolerance and myopathy, hence directly affecting muscles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Von Gierke disease (Ia) is due to Glucose 6 phosphatase deficiency
  • Clinical features include glycogen accumulation in liver and renal tubule cells, hypoglycaemia, lactic acidemia, ketosis and hyperlipidemia. (No muscle weakness).

 

Muscle Glycogen Storage Disorders:

 

 

Ref: Nelson 20/e Defects in the metabolism of Carbohydrates
